class="storytitle"><a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/2017/03/01/r2con-2016-reverseme-challenge/" rel="bookmark">R2con 2016 reverseme challenge</a> </h3><div class="meta">Filed under:  <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/category/conferences/" rel="category tag">Conferences</a>, <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/category/just-for-fun/" rel="category tag">Just for fun</a>, <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/category/reversing/" rel="category tag">Reversing</a> — Tags: <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/tag/challenge/" rel="tag">challenge</a>, href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/tag/linux/" rel="tag">linux</a>, <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/tag/radare/" rel="tag">radare</a>, <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/tag/reverse-engineering/" rel="tag">reverse engineering</a> —  Mario Vilas @ 5:18 pm </div><div class="storycontent"><div data-shortcode="caption" id="attachment_935" style="width: 222px" class="wp-caption alignright"><a href="https://twitter.com/hackerstrip/status/756005526824026112"><img aria-describedby="caption-attachment-935" data-attachment-id="935" data-permalink="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/2017/03/01/r2con-2016-reverseme-challenge/r2con-poster/" data-orig-file="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2017/03/r2con-poster.jpg" data-orig-size="848,1200" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta="{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"0","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":"","orientation":"0"}" data-image-title="r2con-poster" data-image-description="<p>R2con poster</p>" data-image-caption="<p>R2con poster, by the talented artists of Hackerstrip</p>" data-medium-file="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2017/03/r2con-poster.jpg?w=212" data-large-file="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2017/03/r2con-poster.jpg?w=724" class="wp-image-935" src="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2017/03/r2con-poster.jpg?w=212&h=300" alt="R2con poster, by the talented artists of Hackerstrip" width="212" height="300" srcset="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2017/03/r2con-poster.jpg?w=212 212w, https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2017/03/r2con-poster.jpg?w=424 424w, https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2017/03/r2con-poster.jpg?w=106 106w" sizes="(max-width: 212px) 100vw, 212px"></a><p id="caption-attachment-935" class="wp-caption-text">Poster by Hackerstrip</p></div><p><span style="font-size:120%;">Back in September 2016 I attended <a href="http://rada.re/con/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">R2con</a>, the first public and international congress about Radare. Needless to say, it was pretty awesome 😀 and I recommend everyone interested in reverse engineering to go there next year. During the conference, <a href="https://www.riscure.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Riscure</a> proposed a simple reversing challenge using Radare to play with. You can find the challenge <a href="https://github.com/radareorg/r2con/blob/master/2016/challenges/riscureCTF/rhme2-reversing/RHme2_prequalification_challenge" target="_blank" rel="noopener">here</a>. This is my (very short and dumb) writeup of it.</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">The challenge consisted of reversing an ELF binary and figuring out a password. When running the binary, you had to enter the password to get a message saying that you won the challenge. No modifying was allowed, just reversing. Now, this in itself was super easy since it was meant as an introduction, but I didn’t know how to use r2 well enough so it took me a while to solve it. 😀</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">The first problem I ran into was that it used a different version of libcrypto than my distro so I had to set up a VM. I suppose I could have installed another libcrypto and have them coexist, or used a chroot jail or whatever, but just firing up a VM seemed like the easiest choice to me – especially since I’m already used to Vagrant for this kind of thing.</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">After that, it was time to fire up Radare:</span></p><p><code>$ chmod +x RHme2_prequalification_challenge # (did not have the +x bit in Github)<br />$ ./r2 ./RHme2_prequalification_challenge</code></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">Then analyzed everything with the “aaaa” command and launched the UI with “=H” (because I’m lazy). Using the UI I quickly listed the strings, found the relevant ones, then looked for references to them. Turns out everything was right there in main() so this step wasn’t really needed! 😀</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">So, going back to the console, using visual mode we can see the code right away:</span></p><div data-shortcode="caption" id="attachment_951" style="width: 610px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><a href="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2017/03/screenshot-1.png"><img aria-describedby="caption-attachment-951" data-attachment-id="951" data-permalink="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/2017/03/01/r2con-2016-reverseme-challenge/screenshot-1/" data-orig-file="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2017/03/screenshot-1.png" data-orig-size="1011,702" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta="{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"0","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":"","orientation":"0"}" data-image-title="screenshot-1" data-image-description="<p>Gotta love ASCII graph view</p>" data-image-caption="<p>Gotta love ASCII graph view</p>" data-medium-file="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2017/03/screenshot-1.png?w=300" data-large-file="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2017/03/screenshot-1.png?w=1011" class="wp-image-951" src="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2017/03/screenshot-1.png?w=600&h=416" alt="Gotta love ASCII art graph view" width="600" height="416" srcset="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2017/03/screenshot-1.png?w=600 600w, https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2017/03/screenshot-1.png?w=150 150w, https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2017/03/screenshot-1.png?w=300 300w, https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2017/03/screenshot-1.png?w=768 768w, https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2017/03/screenshot-1.png 1011w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px"></a><p id="caption-attachment-951" class="wp-caption-text">Gotta love ASCII art graph view</p></div><p><span style="font-size:120%;">There was some code before the AES decryption that may be some kind of obfuscation, but I didn’t bother with it statically because it was easier to just put a breakpoint at the memory compare after decryption to see what the hardcoded password was.</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">Turns out to run Radare as a debugger you need to specify -d before opening the file. I got stuck there for a while because I’m such a n00b. #shame 😀</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">So, after running “r2 -d”, setting the breakpoint with “db 0x0040081d” then executing the program with “dc”, I got prompted for a password. Just typed anything and continued, after that the breakpoint was hit.</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">From the code I knew the argument with the decoded password should be in the rbx register, so using the “dbr” command to show the registers, then the “s” command to change the pointer (another odd concept for those of us coming from gdb!) and finally using the “x” command I could see the memory contents:</span></p><div data-shortcode="caption" id="attachment_952" style="width: 570px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><a href="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2017/03/screenshot-2.png"><img aria-describedby="caption-attachment-952" data-attachment-id="952" data-permalink="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/2017/03/01/r2con-2016-reverseme-challenge/screenshot-2/" data-orig-file="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2017/03/screenshot-2.png" data-orig-size="677,726" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta="{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"0","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":"","orientation":"0"}" data-image-title="screenshot-2" data-image-description="<p>Gotcha!</p>" data-image-caption="<p>Gotcha!</p>" data-medium-file="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2017/03/screenshot-2.png?w=280" I had no use for most of them and curating them would have been too much of a burden (over 66.000 tweets! so much procrastination!).</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">Now, there are a number of online applications to do that, but they have at least one of the following problems, fundamentally the last one:</span></p><ul><li><span style="font-size:120%;">They pull your Twitter posts from the API, which only allows you to read at most the latest 200 tweets, so removing the older ones becomes impossible.</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;">Some of them get around this by asking you to upload your entire Twitter archive… <del datetime="2016-04-04T05:05:18+00:00">which contains a lot more than just your tweets (i.e. your private messages)</del>. (EDIT: I’m being told this is no longer the case, now it just contains your public timeline)</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;">I don’t trust them.</span></li></ul><p><span style="font-size:120%;">So naturally I rolled my own. The code is crude but it worked for me. It uses the Twitter archive zip file as well, but since it works locally you don’t need to trust a third party with your personal data. With this I managed to delete over 60.000 tweets in a day and a half, roughly – it can’t be done much faster because of the API rate limiting, but then again, what’s the rush? 🙂</span></p><p> <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/2016/04/04/how-to-clean-up-your-twitter-account/#more-890" class="more-link">(more…)</a></p></div><div class="feedback">                        <a I did manage to install both 32 and 64 bit versions though. tag-vulnerability-research" id="post-845"> <h3 class="storytitle"><a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/2014/04/12/heartbleed-and-aslr-misconceptions/" rel="bookmark">Heartbleed and ASLR misconceptions</a> </h3><div class="meta">Filed under:  <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/category/vulnerabilities/" rel="category tag">Vulnerabilities</a> — Tags: <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/tag/vulnerability-research/" rel="tag">vulnerability research</a> —  Mario Vilas @ 1:13 pm </div><div class="storycontent"><h2>TL;DR: <a href="https://xkcd.com/386/" target="_blank">Someone was wrong on the Internet</a> and I just couldn’t help myself. If you already know how memory allocation works you’ll find this post boring and you can skip it. But if you don’t, read on… 🙂</h2><p><img alt=""/><br /><a title="What do you want me to do? LEAVE? Then they'll keep being wrong!" href="https://xkcd.com/386/" target="_blank"><img loading="lazy" class="alignright size-full wp-image-846" src="https://i0.wp.com/imgs.xkcd.com/comics/duty_calls.png" alt="" width="300" height="330"/></a></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">I was just reading an article called “<a href="http://blog.index.hm/post/82388948744/a-look-at-heartbleed-and-why-it-really-isnt-that-bad" target="_blank">A look at Heartbleed and why it really isn’t that bad</a>” and, while I usually tend to agree with anyone who tries to fight against <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fear,_uncertainty_and_doubt" target="_blank">FUD</a>, in this case it happens to be dangerously wrong. I’d write this as a blog comment rather than an entry on my own, but Tumblr seems firmly stuck in the 90’s and won’t even give me that option <img width='16' height='16' class='wp-smiley emoji' draggable='false' alt=':/' src='https://s1.wp.com/wp-content/mu-plugins/wpcom-smileys/uneasy.svg' style='height: 1em; max-height: 1em;' /> so here it goes…</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">In a nutshell, the article downplays the severity of the <a href="http://heartbleed.com/" target="_blank">Heartbleed</a> attack based on the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Address_space_layout_randomization" target="_blank">Address Space Layout Randomization</a> (ASLR) feature of most modern operating systems, that causes memory allocations to be randomized as a mitigation for buffer overflows. The reasoning goes: since memory allocations are random, and the Heartbleed bug allows you to read memory at random as well, the odds of reading important data are pretty much close to zero – therefore the Heartbleed attack is useless and you shouldn’t change your passwords.</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">Ouch.</span></p><p> <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/2014/04/12/heartbleed-and-aslr-misconceptions/#more-845" class="more-link">(more…)</a></p></div><div class="feedback">                        <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/tag/windows/" rel="tag">Windows</a> —  Mario Vilas @ 7:45 pm </div><div class="storycontent"><h2>What is WinAppDbg?</h2><p><span style="font-size:120%;">The WinAppDbg python module allows developers to quickly code instrumentation scripts in Python under a Windows environment.</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">It uses ctypes to wrap many Win32 API calls related to debugging, and provides an object-oriented abstraction layer to manipulate threads, libraries and processes, attach your script as a debugger, trace execution, hook API calls, handle events in your debugee and set breakpoints of different kinds (code, hardware and memory). Additionally it has no native code at all, making it easier to maintain or modify than other debuggers on Windows.</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">The intended audience are QA engineers and software security auditors wishing to test / fuzz Windows applications with quickly coded Python scripts. Several ready to use utilities are shipped and can be used for this purposes.</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">Current features also include disassembling x86/x64 native code, debugging multiple processes simultaneously and produce a detailed log of application crashes, useful for fuzzing and automated testing.</span></p><h2>What’s new in this version?</h2><p><span style="font-size:120%;">In a nutshell…</span></p><ul><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> full 64-bit support (including function hooks!)</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> added support for Windows Vista and above.</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> database code migrated to SQLAlchemy, tested on:</span><ul><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> MySQL</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> SQLite 3</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> Microsoft SQL Server</span></li></ul><p><span style="font-size:120%;">should work on other servers too (let me know if it doesn’t!)</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> added integration with more disassemblers:<ul><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> BeaEngine: <a href="http://www.beaengine.org/">http://www.beaengine.org/</a></span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> Capstone: <a href="http://capstone-engine.org/">http://capstone-engine.org/</a></span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> Libdisassemble: <a href="http://www.immunitysec.com/resources-freesoftware.shtml">http://www.immunitysec.com/resources-freesoftware.shtml</a></span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> PyDasm: <a href="https://code.google.com/p/libdasm/">https://code.google.com/p/libdasm/</a></span></li></ul></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> added support for postmortem (just-in-time) debugging</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> added support for deferred breakpoints</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> now fully supports manipulating and debugging system services</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> the interactive command-line debugger is now launchable from your scripts (thanks Zen One for the idea!)</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> more UAC-friendly, only requests the privileges it needs before any action</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> added functions to work with UAC and different privilege levels, so it’s now possible to run debugees with lower privileges than the debugger</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> added memory search and registry search support</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> added string extraction functionality</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> added functions to work with DEP settings</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> added a new event handler, EventSift, that can greatly simplify coding a debugger script to run multiple targets at the same time</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> added new utility functions to work with colored console output</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> several improvements to the Crash Logger tool</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> integration with already open debugging sessions from other libraries is now possible</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> improvements to the Process and GUI instrumentation functionality</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> implemented more anti-antidebug tricks</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> more tools and code examples, and improvements to the existing ones</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> more Win32 API wrappers</span></li><li><span style="font-size:120%;"> lots of miscellaneous improvements, more documentation and bugfixes as usual!</span></li></ul><h2>Where can I find WinAppDbg?</h2><p><span style="font-size:120%;"><b>Project homepage:</b></span></p><ul><li><span style="font-size:120%;"><a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/2013/04/08/finding-connected-components-in-a-graph/" rel="bookmark">A Python example on finding connected components in a graph</a> </h3><div class="meta">Filed under:  <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/category/programming/" rel="category tag">Programming</a> — Tags: <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/tag/algorithms/" rel="tag">algorithms</a>, <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/tag/linkedin/" rel="tag">LinkedIn</a>, <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/tag/python/" rel="tag">python</a> —  Mario Vilas @ 10:30 pm </div><div class="storycontent"><p><span style="font-size:120%;">Today I’ve been coding a solution for a problem we’ve encountered with <a href="https://twitter.com/ggdaniel">@ggdaniel (cr0hn)</a> during the development of <a href="https://code.google.com/p/golismero/">GoLismero 2.0</a>. It called for an implementation of an algorithm to find <strong>connected components</strong> in an <strong>undirected graph</strong>. You can find the source code at the bottom of this post.</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;"></p><h2>A graph algorithm a day keeps the CS doctor away…</h2><p></span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">Suppose we have an <strong>undirected graph</strong> (connected by lines rather than arrows) in which we can find one or more “islands” of nodes that form connections to each other, but not to nodes in other “islands”. In graph theory, these “islands” are called <strong>connected components</strong>. In the image below, we see a graph with three connected components:</p><p><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pseudoforest.svg"><img src="https://i0.wp.com/upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Pseudoforest.svg/400px-Pseudoforest.svg.png" alt="Example graph with three connected components. Image from Wikipedia." class="aligncenter" /></a></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">Now, suppose we have a set containing all nodes, and we can visit each node to know what are its <strong>neighbors</strong>, that is, the other nodes it’s connected to. We want to find all the connected components and put their nodes into separate sets. How would we do that?</span></p><p> <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/2013/04/08/finding-connected-components-in-a-graph/#more-778" class="more-link">(more…)</a></span></p></div><div class="feedback">                        <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/2013/04/08/finding-connected-components-in-a-graph/#comments">Comments (4)</a></div></div><h2>March 11, 2013</h2><div class="post-754 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-programming tag-algorithms tag-linkedin tag-python" id="post-754"> <h3 class="storytitle"><a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/2013/03/11/an-example-dependency-resolution-algorithm-in-python/" rel="bookmark">An example dependency resolution algorithm in Python</a> </h3><div class="meta">Filed under:  <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/category/programming/" rel="category tag">Programming</a> — Tags: <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/tag/algorithms/" rel="tag">algorithms</a>, <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/tag/linkedin/" rel="tag">LinkedIn</a>, <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/tag/python/" rel="tag">python</a> —  Mario Vilas @ 2:36 pm </div><div class="storycontent"><p><span style="font-size:120%;">I’ve been toying with dependency resolution a bit today, since it’s one of the features we plan to add to <a href="https://code.google.com/p/golismero/">GoLismero 2.0</a> plugins with <a href="https://twitter.com/ggdaniel">@ggdaniel (cr0hn)</a>. So I came up with this short example that’s reasonably fast and doesn’t use recursion at all, unlike many of the examples that I found on the net.</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">The basic idea is this: given a set of tasks (nodes) and the tasks that need to be performed before them, build a dependency graph and find the sets of tasks that can be run concurrently while satisfying the dependencies. For example, suppose we have tasks <strong>A</strong>, <strong>B</strong>, <strong>C</strong> and <strong>D</strong>. Task <strong>A</strong> can be run directly, it has no dependencies. Tasks <strong>B</strong> and <strong>C</strong> must be run only after <strong>A</strong> has completed, so we say <strong>B</strong> and <strong>C</strong> depend on <strong>A</strong>. Then task <strong>D</strong> depends on <strong>B</strong> and <strong>C</strong>, which in turn depend on <strong>A</strong>.</span></p><div data-shortcode="caption" id="attachment_756" style="width: 431px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img aria-describedby="caption-attachment-756" data-attachment-id="756" data-permalink="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/2013/03/11/an-example-dependency-resolution-algorithm-in-python/dependency-example/" data-orig-file="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/dependency-example.png" data-orig-size="421,423" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta="{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"0","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":""}" data-image-title="dependency-example" data-image-description="<p>Dependency graph example</p>" data-image-caption="<p>Dependency graph example</p>" data-medium-file="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/dependency-example.png?w=300" data-large-file="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/dependency-example.png?w=421" loading="lazy" src="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/dependency-example.png?w=421&h=423" alt="Dependency graph example" width="421" height="423" class="size-full wp-image-756" srcset="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/dependency-example.png 421w, https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/dependency-example.png?w=150&h=150 150w, https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/dependency-example.png?w=300&h=300 300w" sizes="(max-width: 421px) 100vw, 421px" /><p id="caption-attachment-756" class="wp-caption-text">Dependency graph example</p></div><p><span style="font-size:120%;">What the algorithm does, instead of traversing the graph recursively, is iteratively finding and removing from the graph all nodes that have no dependencies – that is, no arrows coming out of them. In our example, the first iteration removes node <strong>A</strong>, the second iteration removes nodes <strong>B</strong> and <strong>C</strong>, and the last iteration removes node <strong>D</strong>. And these are precisely the three batches of tasks that can run concurrently – first task <strong>A</strong> runs, on completion tasks <strong>B</strong> and <strong>C</strong> can run in parallel, and once both are finished task <strong>D</strong> can be started.</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">If at some point there are still nodes in the graph but we can’t find any nodes without dependencies, that means we have a circular dependency.</span></p><div data-shortcode="caption" id="attachment_758" style="width: 330px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img rel="bookmark">Navaja Negra (Black Razor) Conference</a> </h3><div class="meta">Filed under:  <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/category/conferences/" rel="category tag">Conferences</a> — Tags: <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/tag/linkedin/" rel="tag">LinkedIn</a> —  Mario Vilas @ 6:39 pm </div><div class="storycontent"><p><span style="font-size:120%;">Just came back today from the <a href="http://navajanegra.com/" target="_blank">Navaja Negra</a> (Black Razor) Conference in Albacete, Spain. Had a great time there, seen lots of old and new faces (they literally filled the room!) and after the talks had a taste of the Albacete nightlife, and a fantastic dinner where I left my mobile phone on the table unattended, and my fellow speakers kindly <a href="https://twitter.com/MarioVilas/status/274671448914808836" title="Well played, well played." target="_blank">reminded</a> me in a polite and civilized manner of the importance of locking one’s phone.</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">This time my friend Aladdin Gurbanov (<a href="https://twitter.com/SeTx_X" title="@SeTx[X]" target="_blank">@SeTx[X]</a>) and I gave a presentation called “Take a walk on the wild side”, an introduction to the world of e-crime on the Internet. I’ll update this post when the slides and the video are online. They’ll be in Spanish only, sorry! Think of it a chance to practice what you learned in Spanish class. 😉</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;"><i><b>Update</b>: Unfortunately not all videos are available! A fragment of our talk is available at <a href="http://ustre.am/RjWO">Ustream</a>. There’s also a summary of the conference (in Spanish) at the <a href="http://www.madesyp.com/news/01012013.php"> MADESYP Academy blog</a>.</i></span></p><p><span><div data-shortcode="caption" id="attachment_726" style="width: 810px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img aria-describedby="caption-attachment-726" data-attachment-id="726" data-permalink="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/2012/12/02/black-razor/navaja_negra_800/" data-orig-file="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2012/12/navaja_negra_800.jpg" data-orig-size="800,285" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta="{"aperture":"0","credit":"Picasa","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"1354467515","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":""}" data-image-title="Navaja Negra 2da edición" data-image-description="<p>That’s my new blade! }:D</p>" data-image-caption="<p>That’s my new blade! }:D</p>" data-medium-file="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2012/12/navaja_negra_800.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2012/12/navaja_negra_800.jpg?w=800" loading="lazy" src="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2012/12/navaja_negra_800.jpg?w=800&h=285" alt="Yup, that's my new knife! }:D" width="800" height="285" class="size-full wp-image-726" srcset="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2012/12/navaja_negra_800.jpg 800w, https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2012/12/navaja_negra_800.jpg?w=150&h=53 150w, https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2012/12/navaja_negra_800.jpg?w=300&h=107 300w, https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2012/12/navaja_negra_800.jpg?w=768&h=274 768w" sizes="(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px" /><p id="caption-attachment-726" class="wp-caption-text">The organization had a really original gift for the speakers this year: a traditional Albacetean <em>Teja</em> black razor.</p></div></span></p></div><div class="feedback">                        <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/2012/12/02/black-razor/#respond">Leave a Comment</a></div></div><h2>September 19, 2012</h2><div class="post-694 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-just-for-fun tag-linkedin tag-python tag-web" id="post-694"> <h3 class="storytitle"><a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/2012/09/19/quickpost-cheating-on-xkcd/" rel="bookmark">Cheating on XKCD</a> </h3><div class="meta">Filed under:  <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/category/just-for-fun/" rel="category tag">Just for fun</a> — Tags: <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/tag/linkedin/" rel="tag">LinkedIn</a>, <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/tag/python/" rel="tag">python</a>, <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/tag/web/" rel="tag">web</a> —  Mario Vilas @ 3:23 pm </div><div class="storycontent"><p><span style="font-size:120%;">In case you missed it, today’s XKCD comic titled <a href="http://xkcd.com/1110/">Click and Drag</a> is simply amazing! Go check it out first, spend a few hours lost in it, and come back only when you’re done having fun. I’ll wait here. 🙂</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">…</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">Ok, you’re back. Naturally you’ll want to cheat on it at some point, to make sure you didn’t miss out on any hidden easter eggs! So let’s take a look at the web page.</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">The easiest route is loading the comic on Google Chrome, or Chromium. Just right click on the image and select “inspect element”. This quickly reveals how the neat trick works.</span></p><div data-shortcode="caption" id="attachment_696" style="width: 924px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><a href="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/click-and-drag-how-it-works.png"><img aria-describedby="caption-attachment-696" data-attachment-id="696" data-permalink="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/2012/09/19/quickpost-cheating-on-xkcd/click-and-drag-how-it-works/" data-orig-file="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/click-and-drag-how-it-works.png" data-orig-size="914,438" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta="{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"0","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":""}" data-image-title="click-and-drag-how-it-works" data-image-description="<p>Taking a peek under the hood…</p>" data-image-caption="<p>Taking a peek under the hood…</p>" data-medium-file="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/click-and-drag-how-it-works.png?w=300" data-large-file="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/click-and-drag-how-it-works.png?w=914" loading="lazy" class="size-full wp-image-696" title="click-and-drag-how-it-works" src="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/click-and-drag-how-it-works.png?w=914&h=438" alt="Taking a peek under the hood..." width="914" height="438" srcset="https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/click-and-drag-how-it-works.png 914w, https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/click-and-drag-how-it-works.png?w=150&h=72 150w, https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/click-and-drag-how-it-works.png?w=300&h=144 300w, https://breakingcode.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/click-and-drag-how-it-works.png?w=768&h=368 768w" sizes="(max-width: 914px) 100vw, 914px" /></a><p id="caption-attachment-696" class="wp-caption-text">Taking a peek under the hood…</p></div><p><span style="font-size:120%;">The “world” is divided into tiles of fixed size, and at all times the page loads the tile you’re currently viewing and the surrounding ones, in order to seamlessly stitch them together when scrolling. The clickable area is a map and the coordinates are used to build the URL to the images, which always follows the same pattern (north, south, and east and west coordinates). Trying out a few numbers reveals the “north” coordinate goes from 1 to 5, the “east” coordinate goes from 1 to 48 and the “west” coordinate goes from 1 to 33. Not all coordinates seem to work around the edges of the world (north 2 west 5 doesn’t work for example) and I couldn’t get south to work with manual tries. I suppose a couple empty images are used for those (one for black and one for white) but I didn’t confirm it.</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">The first thing I tried was just accesing the parent directory to see if directory indexing was enabled, but no such luck. Instead, I wrote <a href="http://winappdbg.sourceforge.net/blog/xkcd-click-drag.py">this quick and dirty script</a> in Python to download all images, using urllib to download them and shutil to write them to disk. Missing tiles are simply skipped.</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;">This should be enough to check for easter eggs, but it’d be interesting of someone assembles a big image containing all the tiles. Let me know if you do! 🙂</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;"><b>Update 1:</b> I originally missed the east coordinate, so the script was updated to try and bruteforce in all directions 1 to 10 north and south, and 1 to 50 east and west. This means a lot more HTTP requests, so I also added a pause between them as good netizens should.</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;"><b>Update 2:</b> This seems to be the <a href="http://winappdbg.sourceforge.net/blog/xkcd-click-drag.txt">complete list</a> of valid image URLs.</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;"><b>Update 3:</b> A commenter pointed out somebody did assemble the entire world image! <a href="http://kittenofdiscord.blogspot.de/2012/09/xkcd-click-and-drag-without-drag.html">Check it out here</a>.</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;"><b>Update 4:</b> <a href="https://twitter.com/prigazzi">@prigazzi</a> on Twitter pointed out <del datetime="2012-12-30T21:31:35+00:00"><a href="http://198.71.94.49/xkcd/">this fully navegable map</a></del> as well, based on Google Maps. Check it out! It’s IMHO the best one yet. 🙂</span></p><p><span style="font-size:120%;"><b>Update 5:</b> The previous link no longer works, but this works pretty much the same way: <a title="xkcd-map.rent-a-geek.de" href="http://xkcd-map.rent-a-geek.de/">xkcd-map.rent-a-geek.de</a></span></p><p> <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/2012/09/19/quickpost-cheating-on-xkcd/#more-694" class="more-link">(more…)</a></p></div><div class="feedback">                        <a href="https://breakingcode.wordpress.com/2012/09/19/quickpost-cheating-on-xkcd/#comments">Comments
